awd_titl_txt: Holomorphic Invariants of Knots and Contact Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
Symplectic geometry is an area of mathematics that dates back to the 19th century, with its roots in physics and Newtonian mechanics. In the past few decades, symplectic geometry has emerged as an exciting and fundamental area of mathematical research, due in part to close connections with many other parts of mathematics as well as physics. It has had especially striking recent applications to topology, the study of geometric shapes and spaces, and particularly the theory of knots, loops of string that are tied together at their ends. The Principal Investigator will apply ideas from symplectic geometry to construct and study invariants of knots as well as geometric spaces in three and higher dimensions. Preliminary past work suggests that these invariants provide a surprising and unexpected bridge between several modern areas of mathematics (symplectic geometry, algebraic geometry, and quantum knot theory) and physics (string theory, a model for the fundamental forces that shape the universe). This project will explore this bridge, with the goal of creating and strengthening new lines of two-way communication between mathematics and theoretical physics. As part of this project, the Principal Investigator will also promote the training of early-career researchers in mathematics, especially through research experiences in mathematics for undergraduate students. In addition the project will provide research training opportunities for graduate students.

The project supported by this award will focus on several related lines of research, all centered around holomorphic curves, which have become central to the modern study of symplectic geometry since work of Gromov in the 1980s. One direction builds on the construction of Fukaya categories, algebraic structures associated to symplectic manifolds that play a key role in Homological Mirror Symmetry. The present project will construct a version of the Fukaya category for contact manifolds, built out of knots in a contact manifold. A key motivation for studying this category for contact manifolds is that it can serve as a central repository for holomorphic-curve invariants of the contact manifold. In particular, it will be a key intermediary in a larger picture that brings together other categories, both geometric (infinitesimal Fukaya categories) and algebraic (microlocal sheaf categories). Another aspect of the project deals with a package of knot invariants called knot contact homology, which has been studied by the Principal Investigator in previous work. This project will investigate the connection between knot contact homology and certain other knot invariants such as HOMFLY-PT polynomials, using recent progress in topological string theory. Goals in this direction include developing a formula for colored HOMFLY-PT polynomials in terms of holomorphic curves and quantizing the augmentation variety, a knot invariant devised from knot contact homology, to produce a recurrence relation for these polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The PI's research supported by this grant focused on developing new techniques to study longstanding problems in symplectic geometry. Symplectic geometry is an area of mathematics that arises from the study of classical mechanics in physics. In the past few decades, symplectic geometry has emerged as an important subject with close ties to other areas of mathematics such as topology and algebraic geometry, as well as to areas of physics such as string theory.

The PI's work centers around certain algebraic structures in symplectic geometry that come from counting geometric objects called holomorphic curves. The technique of counting holomorphic curves in symplectic manifolds was pioneered in the 1980s and 1990s by Mikhail Gromov, Andreas Floer, and others, and has been responsible for many recent breakthroughs in both symplectic geometry and low-dimensional topology. The PI used holomorphic curves to study a key class of knots in three-dimensional space called Legendrian knots. In this setting, there is a powerful invariant of Legendrian knots, Legendrian contact homology, which is based on holomorphic curve counts and has revolutionized the study of Legendrian knots in the past 25 years. The PI's work demonstrated that Legendrian contact homology can be extended to a much more intricate, and potentially stronger, algebraic invariant known as an L-infinity structure. Unlike many holomorphic-curve invariants, this new structure is easy to compute because of its combinatorial nature.

In a related direction, in collaboration with Roger Casals, the PI developed a new geometric application of Legendrian contact homology. This application involved the classification of certain surfaces called Lagrangian fillings whose boundaries lie on a Legendrian knot. Casals and the PI proved that several families of Legendrian knots have infinitely many distinct Lagrangian fillings. This followed results of a similar nature by several groups of mathematicians, using markedly different techniques such as cluster theory, but the techniques developed by Casals and the PI are applicable to many classes of knots that are currently inaccessible by other methods.

A different joint paper by Robert Lipshitz and the PI resolved a decades-old open problem about Legendrian contact homology, proving that an algebraic phenomenon called torsion can appear in a linear version of Legendrian contact homology.

Broader impacts:

This grant supported the work of 4 PhD students working with the PI, two of whom have graduated with their PhD and two of whom are currently being advised by the PI, as well as two postdoctoral researchers. The PI organized "Frontiers in Geometry and Topology," a 2022 summer school and conference, and edited a proceedings volume of the same name, now published by the American Mathematical Society.

During the course of this grant, the PI also worked to support and promote research in mathematics at the undergraduate level. Specifically, the PI served as the director of Math+, a summer program in collaborative research organized by the Duke Mathematics Department. Over the period of this grant, the PI oversaw 25 Math+ projects involving 85 undergraduate students, 7 of whom were directly supported by this grant. The grant also supported 2 other undergraduate research projects through PRUV, another summer research program at Duke University.
